captions.text:
Say dawg, welcome back to Thug
Notes. This week we workin it with Of Mice
and Men by John Steinbeck.

This book tell the story of two
ranch hands: a skinny hood named George and

some gumby lookin mofo named Lennie who be
a bit goofy in the head. Naw mean? See, even

though Lennie’s simple ass love to pet soft
animals, he too swoll to handle em without
bustin em up.

So as mah boys rollin up to their
new gig, George starts droppin some righteous

talk bout how once they stack enough dough,
they gonna buy their own farm and live the

high life with no hassles. And Big Lennie
even gonna have his own rabbits to tend to.

At the ranch, George and Lenny peep some wrinkly
old timer named Candy, who been workin that

farm since fo- eva. Out of nowhere, the boss-man’s
son Curley steps to and starts messin wit

Lenny fo no reason. Also, turns out Curley
just married some hoochie who like to buss

it wit the other farm hands. George tells
Lenny he best stay away from dat trick.

When Lenny and George start
jabberin again bout their dream of livin like

high ballers, Candy jumps in and say he could
lend them some scratch and live wit them on
that farm.

Wit the promise of Candy’s cash
money, they realize they only got one mo month

of hustlin before they can start livin high
off the hog.

Later, Curley’s wife peeps Lennie
chillin all by his lonesome and starts teasin

mah boy. After she axe him if he wanna touch
her hair, Lennie gets amped and starts stroking

too rough. Just when she bout to squawk, Lenny
tweaks out and accidentally snaps her neck.
Whoo!

Lennie gets all scrred that George
gonna be mad and bails. When Curly finds his

biddy lyin stiff, he rallies his posse to
hunt Lennie down.

But before the lynch mob can ghost
Lenny, George finds him chillin at a creek.

Lenny axe George to talk about their dream
crib again to calm him down. As George lullin

Lenny wit those sweet dreams of easy livin,
he pulls out a piece and puts a hot one right
in Lenny’s dome. Dayum.

Aight B, you just ain’t graspin the
title of this book without checkin this poem
by Robert Burns.

Just like Bobby B doin in his poem,
Steinbeck droppin some raw talk bout how although

the American Dream promising a righteous life
to erryone who got the juice to hustle, it
ain’t nothin but an illusion.

See, up in this backwards-ass
society, shysti rich folk stackin bread at

the expense of the weak and po, who bein robbed
of their basic human dignity. So what Steinbeck

preachin up in here is that dreams that exist
in a culture of exploitation ain’t never
gonna be nothin but dreams.

So are we supposed to be like dem tight-ass
rich folk who only look

out for themselves, or should we help a brotha
out? If you keepin it allegorical up in here,

you could say Steinbeck posin the same question
that Cain axe God in the story of Cain and
Abel: “Am I my brother’s keeper?”

So let’s get all biblical up in
this heezy. In Genesis 4:12, God lays the
hurt on Cain by sayin:

Since Cain spilled dat kindred
blood, he ain’t never gonna enjoy the fruits

of his labor no matter how much he hustles.
And since my boys thuggin it up in a world

tainted by the curse of Cain, that farm Lennie
and George always dreamin about ain’t never

gonna happen. Cuz, as my boy Steinbeck suggestin
by naming his character George Milton- Paradise
is lost play boy.

You could also say this book
critiquing Judeo-Christian morality, playa.

See my boys Lenny and George reppin two opposin
aspects of humanity. Lenny be all the animal

appetites that peeps always tryin to deny
which is why he always wanna pet soft things.

Whereas my boy George representin
that voice of reason that try to control dem

beastly desires. That’s why George always
tellin Lennie what to do.

When George pumps a hot one in
Lenny’s skull, it’s like he’s tryin

to destroy man’s animal impulses. So to
rep that Jude-Christian Morality, mah boy
gotta ice his day 1 brutha- just like Cain.

Yo thanks for showin all da love.
Keep it gangsta and tune in next week.

title: Of Mice and Men - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
At first, Thug Notes reveals to me my own incompetence to judge the message 
of authors.  However, Ray Bradbury in his critique of the response to 
Fahrenheit 451 makes clear to me that almost no one seems to understand 
what an author is writing about, ever.  Art is, as always, subject to 
interpretation.﻿
comments.author: Joshua Schmidlkofer

comments.text: I love Thug Notes
comments.author: Chana Phaedra

comments.text:
I would argue that it's about the latter with a little bit extra, saying 
that we have to give up any semblance of innocence and animal nature to 
reap any rewards. Although the book doesn't say anything about what happens 
to George afterwards, it's assumed that he lives a peaceful life without 
Lennie, especially when he refers to Lennie as a burden. Now of course 
that's not a Steinbeck saying that it's good, but a criticism of our times 
and how people like Lennie are no longer fit for this world. Compare with 
Native Son, where society makes a monster out of someone innocent, where as 
Lennie was born both and society can't keep him.﻿

comments.text:
So basically the book is saying "fuck capitalism." No argument there except 
it's not just capitalism that was their obstacle. After all they wanted to 
own a farm so they kinda needed to have private property rights to meet 
their goal in the first place. The book is set in the Great Depression, 
they're not exactly descended from the bourgoisie, and Lenny causes hangups 
by mistake, so many of their obstacles were situational and had nothing to 
do with the have's vs. have-not's.
Basically just because they have their dream, no matter how hard they work 
it's not gurranteed that it'll happen.﻿
comments.author: Zach Martinez

comments.text:
+Joshua Schmidlkofer​ I will admit however that I do prefer your

comments.author: Tracy Fisher

comments.text:
+Joshua Schmidlkofer​ that's a good interpetation, though doesn't greed and 
isolation have a source? China and Russia (in my opinion anyway) do not/ 
did not (whichever you prefer) practice communism properly anyway, in a 
communist society people are supposed to share equally however the leaders 
abuse their power, that is what creates the problems in those countries not 
communism
comments.author: Tracy Fisher

comments.text:
+Tracy Fisher When people blame "capitalism" for human nature, they ignore 
the ultimately fascist/totalitarian Nazi's, and the Communists of Russia or 
China.  Greed and isolation are problems with which the world grapples as 
one.  The experience of Liberty is able to produce greater abundance, 
greater reach and a Greater Species.  Yet, freedom implies that the worst 
of humanity can likewise we increased as well.  So, indicting a system of 
economics is literally like blaming your parents because you do not share 
your "chedda".  

Now, blaming the endless, worrying and troublesome government interference 
in every part of human lives is a much better analogy.  For all we know, 
the land owner represents the government in this story.
comments.author: Joshua Schmidlkofer

comments.text:
Yeah I agree with the point that this book is against capitalism; Steinbeck 
teaches the dangers of loneliness through all the different characters and 
how we need each other and capitalism goes against that and is basically 
'every man for himself'. By showing how dependant we are on each other 
Steinbeck teaches the hardships of living in a society that promotes 
working to keep yourself alive at any cost (i.e: exploiting people) and 
implies that we should work together not against each other, down with 
capitalism lol.
comments.author: Tracy Fisher

comments.text:
Well, yeah. It doesn't really say a lot about economics and John Steinbeck

interested in such a topic.

comments.text:
I also feel they missed key symbolism regarding inequality for people like 
blacks, women, and the disabled (mental and physical). This was shown 
through the fact that the farm hand, candy, Lenny, and curly's wife were 
always left behind and deprived of certain privileges. This was even 
verbalized in the novel. Those are just my thoughts﻿

just don't think there was that much symbolism in the book. The fact that 
George killed Lenny wasn't like Cain killing Abel--Cain killed Abel because 
he was jealous that Abel's offering to God was accepted better than his 
own....George wasn't jealous of Lenny?﻿

comments.text:

two perhaps, but you're saying its more a biblical reference/plot? Havnt 
read it since I was a kid but I didn't get that...idk. its already a really

literature), but eden? Personaly....tha central valley really ain't aaall

comments.author: lengua muerta

comments.text:
Yeah, but his description of the rural idyll in Of Mice and Men in 
particular is supposed to symbolise Eden.
comments.author: TheBlindedAdventurer

comments.text:
+TheBlindedAdventurer ehh...many of his books were based around the salinas 
valley area
comments.author: lengua muerta

comments.text:
That is a good point, however you must also realise that the beginning of 
the novella gives a description of the area around the Salinas River, with 
stuff like "willows deep and green" and "golden hills". This description is 
actually supposed to be symbolic of the garden of Eden, linking to the 
whole "paradise lost" thing Steinebck's got goin' on. So that's probably 
what most links the Of Mice and Men to the biblical stories.
comments.author: TheBlindedAdventurer

comments.text:

comments.author: Tekvicious

comments.text:
The parallels between Cain and Abel (CA) are that OF Mice and Men (OMAM) 
poses the question of are we our 'brother's keeper' which CA also does with 
Cain asking God that question. George in OMAM believes that we are whilst 
he farm owners disagree.

On top of this, after Cain kills Abel, he must walk around the world by 
himself and wants to die of loneliness. George will now be lonely because 
Lennie is gone. Steinbeck does this to return to the theme of loneliness 
(as he does in many of his works - notably 'Grapes of Wrath') and to 
encourage the migrant people to unite and to be the keepers of each other 
like George was to Lennie.
comments.author: Jonathan Buchanan

comments.text: Jesus was a sodomite
comments.author: HoneyBooBooChile

comments.text:
Disregarding the bible reference in the video, Of Mice and Men is 
definitely full of symbolism. Like, undoubtedly. There are so many themes 
going on. It's practically an allegory. It can be kinda hard to see though, 
because Steinbeck's writing is so simple and easy to grasp—we're used to 
seeing symbolism as being very cryptic.
comments.author: Nathan Richan

comments.text: Elijah, what a load of shit
comments.author: Ben Grezik

comments.text:
Would you like to go to the Bible? I'd love to--how about we go Deuteronomy 
27:26, which says that we're CURSED if we don't follow the entire Law. 

That's impossible! Literally, if we break one tiny rule, we just sent 
ourselves to Hell. That's why the Law POINTS to Jesus Christ, because 
Christ is the way for salvation. Look at what Galatians 3 says--

Galatians 3 says that the Law was made to show us what sin was, and to show 
us how much we're sinning (whether we intentionally do it or not). So 
there's no way we can follow the whole Law. 

THAT'S why we should be so thankful that Jesus Christ came here to 
sacrifice Himself for our sake, and so that way, we can get forgiven 
through Him.
comments.author: Elijah Olson

Nah, I reckon Lenny had to kill George like he had to kill the child in 
himself and his dreams. As much as he tried to keep the softhearted, 
wistful side of him going, there's no room for it when you're living the 
life of an exploited farmhand.
People act like those folk should be happy they're fed, clothed and 
sheltered, but they don't know what living that life does to your soul.﻿

comments.text:
+nikoincroatia
Sorry! But don't worry, it's not the finale like in Of Mice and Men. It 
happens within the first 20 minutes or so. But seriously, go watch it. I 
know you'll love it. If you've seen any of Kubrick's other movies (2001: A 
Space Odyssey, The Shining, A Clockwork Orange), you'll know what to expect.
comments.author: Nathan Richan

comments.text: +Nathan Richan I haven't seen it. Spoiler alert, man!
comments.author: nikoincroatia

comments.text:
I agree. Have you seen Full Metal Jacket? You'd prolly love it. Private 
Pyle and Joker are pretty much the same as Lenny and George, the only 
difference being that George kills Lenny whereas Pyle kills himself (and 
the boot-camp instructor).

An interesting thing to point out about that scene is that it's most likely 
a dream sequence, going on while Joker sleeps. There's lots of evidence to 
support this, probably the most convincing being that the bathroom where 
the scene takes place is called 'The Head' (we dream in our head). Also, 
the bathroom is a spacial impossibility.
comments.author: Nathan Richan

comments.text:
The analogy between Lenny and Abel is that they where both just feeling for 
the sake of feeling instead of for any kind of gain. Lenny just liked 
petting the soft rabbits, so much that it hurt them, because he was not 
thinking. That fits into your definition of animalism. Abel was just making 
offerings because it made him feel good, he was not thinking about the way 
his actions where hurting Cain and his relationship with god, just as Lenny 
was not thinking about his actions affecting Georges plans. I agree with 
The idea that this is a critique of the bible story because it turns the 
moral implications of the story on its head, with this interpretation, no 
longer is Cain the villain and Abel the victim, God is the villain, Abel is 
the device, and Cain is the victim.
comments.author: Ben Grezik

comments.text:
+Ben Grezik Your definition of animalistic overlaps with innocence.
I agree that animals are mostly pretty innocent and chill, but the word 
animalistic has negative connotations due to the old misconception that 
animals are less empathetic and emotionally intelligent than humans.
comments.author: nikoincroatia

comments.text: You and I have 2 different definitions of animalistic.
comments.author: Ben Grezik

comments.text:
I view innocence as good or neutral intentions combined with ignorance. 
When we describe someone as animalistic, we mean that they act out of base 
desires with no regard for the wellbeing of others. Lenny does not qualify 
because he understands and regrets the pain of others, and does not intend 
to cause it.
comments.author: nikoincroatia

comments.text: Animals are innocent too
comments.author: Ben Grezik

comments.text:
+Ben Grezik The difference is that Lenny acts out of innocence. He doesn't 
hurt others because he doesn't understand that it is wrong, he does it 
because he is a child in the body of a giant man.
comments.author: nikoincroatia

comments.text:
But what really is the distinction between child like tendencies, and 
animal like tendencies?
comments.author: Ben Grezik

comments.author: ActionHank75

comments.text: WOW, I'd never heard of that Biblical analysis before.. Deep!﻿
comments.author: addicted92

comments.text:
I wish the summary was more in depth but I love the analysis of the book. I 
agree with him when he talks about the American dream and how it is just an 
allusion. Back in the 1930's everyone had a dream of living big with a lot 
of money but it never happened because economy was down and the were not 
being realistic about their dreams. The way he mention the bible and how it 
all connected to the story made me think about it because I did not think 
it would be based on something in the bible.﻿
comments.author: Erandy Lopez

comments.text: finally a funny youtube channel ﻿
comments.author: randomshow122

comments.text:
Its been years since I read this book but I really like the analysis and 
biblical reference. It kind of made sense that George and Lenny were like 
Cain and Abel except the only difference was that George didn't kill out of 
jelousy but because he had to. I also agree with the message about living 
the american dream, many people dream of working hard enough to get what 
they desire but in the end its the wealthy people who benefit from their 
hard work. ﻿
comments.author: Denise Garcia

comments.text: "some gumby looking goofy mofo" LOL﻿
comments.author: Luis Villar

comments.text:
I agree with the analysis, Jorges and lennys dream of owning a farm was a 
direct allusion to americans wanting to live the american dream, lenny 
being shot in the head represented all those dreams never happening, Hated 
jorge for killing lenny ﻿
comments.author: Samuel Zarate

comments.text:
I did not get that biblical reference and it really helps me understand the 
book more, the ending was really unfortunate but I understand it had to be 
done and why it had to be, the others would've killed him either way not 
considering the fact that his intelligence level isn't all up in the air so 
in some way it isnt really his fault ﻿
comments.author: Luis Tirado

comments.text: Fucking saved my GCSE cheers man!﻿
comments.author: James Thorpe

comments.text: Sparky Sweets is like the hood version of John Hurt, The Storyteller...nice﻿
comments.author: Kl Malcom

comments.text:
Really good analysis! The only thing that I would've liked was the summary 
to be more in depth and a little longer. What I liked is how he described 
how dreams will always be dreams for certain reasons. What I feel what he 
meant by this was that maybe if people don't motivate themselves to turn a 
dream into reality then dreams just stay in ones head and never open up to 
actually be in real life.﻿
comments.author: Jazmine Zavalza

comments.text: Making me realize just how many biblical allusions this story has /(.-.)\﻿
comments.author: Sheyla Cervantes

comments.text:
The way he interpreted the idea that dreams will always be dreams is still 
a way to see things today. The economy wasn't all that great then and it's 
not at its greatest at the moment either. The idea that a persons' dreams 
wont become reality can still be thought of today. Either people don't have 
the money to fulfill their dream or they don't have the motivation to do 
so. Unfortunately, i believe that a majority of the time it would be 
because of fees and so on. I actually really enjoy the fact that he 
referred back to the bible and relate it to the book, that's would be the 
background information and perhaps where the idea of this scene came 
through. ﻿
comments.author: Monse G

comments.text: Wow..I read this book and you got in waayy deeper than I did..awesome!﻿
comments.author: Chessa Rofloski

comments.text:
This was a good interpretation of Mice and Men. Before watching this video 
I did not even consider it to be based on anything referring to the bible. 
However after watching this video it made much more sense as a whole. I 
agree that Jorge was portrayed as the logical and reason in the novel 
because he always made Lenny's dreams more reasonable and took care of him 
because he was brighter and knew Lenny couldn't think for himself. It also 
made me question whether John Steinbeck was a religious person? ﻿
comments.author: andrea valverde

comments.text:
I think this book can reflect people living in the lower class showing that 
no matter how hard they work it seems like the " American dream" will never 
be achieved, there is always something hindering their success.﻿
comments.author: Rakayla Simpson

comments.text:
I really loved this book, from the moment i opened it i was captivated by 
the story. stienback used simple words that readers could understand but 
yet it got throught the complex themes without over simplifying﻿
comments.author: falloutjustcause

comments.text:
It's been a while since I've read of mice and men. I read it my freshman 
year and as soon as I saw the video it's like though whole book was 
recapped in my mind. I remember how much I used to sympathize for lennie 
because he was so sweet but he destroyed everything he touched without 
meaning to. I also dislike George so much for killing his "friend". They 
could have escaped together. I mean if anyone's going to kill lennie it 
should have been curly. ﻿
comments.author: Kimberly Uribe

comments.text:
One thing I will never understand is why George decides to kill Lennie. I 
understand that Lennie made a mistake, and in it he killed a lady,  but 
these were the old times and I believe that Lennie  could have been 
controlled and looked after. I'm sure that if George didn't kill him, maybe 
the farmer's son would have, but this is unclear to me which is why is 
causes questioning.﻿
comments.author: EstherMalicious

comments.text:
It's odd how George said he hated Lennie, but he actually loved him very 
much.
comments.author: Julian Escobedo

comments.text:
Lennie would have been killed in a horrific fashion by Curly's mob.  He 
would have been strung up and "hanged from the neck until death".  George 
realizes this, and in an act of mercy "releases" his friend from his mortal 
coil.  Lennie's last thought are of his beloved rabbits rather than the 
confusion and fear of the mob.  George now must shoulder the guilt of 
killing his best friend from this day forth; and even if he successfully 
purchases a farm, his success, no matter how meagrely, is tainted.
comments.author: Doug Thompson

comments.text:
Yes everyone has dreams the way Lenny and George had one to build a farm 
and sadly it didn't happen for them. Not all the time the dreams that mean 
a lot to you will come true because it will come in the way and sometimes 
there isn't much to do about it. I also liked how there was comparison on 
Lenny and George by reflecting that there is some people like that.﻿
comments.author: Alexis Martinez
